title: Pearl S. Buck - Nobel Prize in Literature, 1938 (38 books)
description:
PEARL S. BUCK (1892-1973) was an American writer and novelist.  She received the 1938 Nobel Prize in Literature "for her rich and truly epic descriptions of peasant life in China and for her biographical masterpieces."

The following books are in ePUB format unless otherwise indicated:

== NOVELS ==

* Angry Wife, The (Open Road, 2013)
* Big Wave, The (Open Road, 2012)
* Come, My Beloved (Open Road, 2013)
* Death in the Castle (Open Road, 2013)
* Dragon Seed (Open Road, 2012)
* East Wind: West Wind (Open Road, 2012)
* Eternal Wonder, The (Open Road, 2013)
* Goddess Abides, The (Open Road, 2013)
* God's Men (Open Road, 2013)
* Good Earth, The [House of Earth Trilogy 1] (Open Road, 2012)
* Hidden Flower, The (Open Road, 2013)
* House Divided, A [House of Earth Trilogy 3] (Open Road, 2012)
* Imperial Woman (Open Road, 2013)
* Kinfolk (Open Road, 2012)
* Letter from Peking (Open Road, 2013)
* Living Reed, The (Open Road, 2012)
* Mother, The (Open Road, 2012)
* New Year, The (John Day, 1968) -- PDF
* Patriot, The (Open Road, 2013)
* Pavilion of Women (Open Road, 2012)
* Peony (Open Road, 2012)
* Portrait of a Marriage (Open Road, 2013)
* Promise, The (Open Road, 2012)
* Rainbow, The (John Day, 1974) -- PDF
* Satan Never Sleeps (Pocket Books, 1962) -- PDF
* Sons [House of Earth Trilogy 2] (Open Road, 2012)
* This Proud Heart (Open Road, 2013)
* Three Daughters of Madame Liang, The (Pocket Books, 1971) -- PDF
* Time is Noon, The (Open Road, 2013)


== SHORT STORIES ==

* Far and Near: Stories of Japan, China, and America (John Day, 1947) -- PDF
* Fourteen Stories (Pocket Books, 1963) -- PDF
* Woman Who Was Changed & Other Stories, The (Crowell, 1979) -- PDF


== AUTOBIOGRAPHIES ==

* Bridge for Passing, A (Open Road, 2013)
* My Several Worlds (Open Road, 2013)


== NON-FICTION ==

* Chinese Novel, The: Nobel Lecture (Macmillan, 1939) -- PDF
* Child Who Never Grew: A Memoir  (Open Road, 2013)
* For Spacious Skies [with Theodore F. Harris] (John Day, 1966) -- PDF
* Nobel Acceptance Speech (Nobel Library, 1971) -- PDF
